awd_titl_txt: BD Spokes: SPOKE: MIDWEST: Collaborative: Integrative Materials Design (IMaD): Leverage, Innovate, and Disseminate
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials innovation is a pipeline, deriving from a deep understanding and control of material behavior and properties, leading to advanced materials designs that advance economic prosperity, address national and regional energy needs, and bolster national security. Improving this pipeline requires connecting independent but thematically congruent national and regional materials design efforts to align key stakeholders, consolidate diverse materials data expertise, simplify data access, coalesce on topics of data description and interoperability, enhance and ensure the quality of datasets, and deploy scalable data services to support materials researchers. The Midwest Big Data Spoke (MBD Spoke) for Integrative Materials Design (IMaD) connects researchers in industry, universities, and government to the people and services needed to easily find, access, and use data, tools, and services for materials design. The Midwest is the ideal place for such a program. Many major national materials design efforts funded by DOE, NIST, and NSF as part of the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) operate in the Midwest, and the Midwest is home to major manufacturing industries that depend critically on materials innovation for their continued competitiveness.

The technical work of IMaD will involve integration of software and services from across the Midwest and beyond, including the Materials Commons, the Materials Data Facility, NIST Materials Resource Registry, and Citrine Informatics, to enable smooth flow of software and data among these different systems. For example, integrated authentication provided by Globus Auth will enable access to different components with common credentials (e.g., institutional credentials), and integration of Globus transfer will allow for rapid and reliable exchange of large datasets. Common schemas and metadata terms will be developed and deployed to permit cross-system searching and display of information. Materials data from partners across the Midwest and beyond will be loaded into the Material Data Facility to permit easy discovery and access. Concurrently with these and other development activities, a series of workshops and meetings will be convened to engage academic, government, and industry participants in defining requirements for, and making use of, the integrated system for materials design.

This award received co-funding from the Math and Physical Sciences Directorate (MPS) Division of Materials Research (DMR).

por.por_cntn:
Accelerating and broadening the pipeline of basic research innovation in materials science into practical applications to address societal needs, drive economic prosperity, and boost national security requires connecting efforts from a variety of independent national and regional materials design efforts to: simplify data access, align key stakeholders, consolidate diverse materials data expertise, coalesce on topics of data description and interoperability, enhance and ensure the dataset quality, and deploy and maintain modern scalable data services. This project worked to support materials researchers across the country, by leveraging and synthesizing existing tools to form a more cohesive materials data infrastructure. The Midwest Big Data Hub (MBDH) Integrative Materials Design (IMaD) Spoke helped to begin realizing these goals by connecting researchers in industry, universities, and government to the people and services needed to easily find, access, and use data, tools, and services for materials design.

 

The major goals of the IMaD project were to 1) leverage and integrate the expertise, services, facilities, and community connections, and unique datasets of the IMaD partners; 2) innovate to expedite and advance materials design by promoting and simplifying materials data sharing and discovery across existing services; and 3) to collect, index, and distribute Midwest materials datasets.

 

[1] Leverage: We made significant progress in outreach to other materials data related efforts and to companies with ties to manufacturing (Citrine Informatics, 3M, Questek, MilliporeSigma). Further, we have shared significant: 1) knowledge of machine learning and materials informatics knowledge between groups at University of Wisconsin-Madison and University of Chicago, including building collaborative cross-institution undergraduate projects and development of two new joint proposals that led to a newly funded project; 2) knowledge of underlying infrastructure (e.g., University of Michigan - Materials Commons and University of Chicago - Globus); 3) shared development via small team meetings and community hackathons (e.g., DOE facility Hackathon, AFRL/NIST Hackathon, and the NIST/CHiMaD  Materials Microscopy Data Workshop); and 4) shared results with the community via workshops, new courseware, and incorporation of key concepts into MaRDA. In the  past year, MaRDA has emerged as a launchpad for sustained, community-scale projects and its grassroots volunteer network has grown to more than 325 members representing academia, industry, national labs, repositories, infrastructure providers, publishers, instrument manufacturers, teaching faculty, and funding agencies. MaRDA has hosted two annual meetings, which are among the largest (~200 attendees for the 2021 meeting), most diverse gatherings focused on materials data in the world.

 

[2] Innovate: A key goal of IMaD was to integrate various technologies and data services in the materials science community, beginning with those of the IMaD partners. IMaD and MDF together have made progress in connecting various components in the data ecosystem. In Years 1-5, we connected 12 data services with varying levels of connectivity (see supporting Figure), and also built support for data ingest from a number of cloud storage providers.

 

[3] Collect, index, and distribute: Another goal was to collect data from partners and make them more easily available to the community and to communicate these concepts to the broader public. We made progress by collecting datasets or making data service connections with each partner institution: Wisconsin -  STEM image database and dilute diffusion coefficient database; Illinois MgO diffusion data, stopping power datasets, connections to 4CeeD service; Michigan - initial connections between MDF/Globus and Materials Commons; Northwestern - data from CHiMaD collaborators, polymer property database, datasets to enable discovery of materials for Li-ion battery electrolytes, and  connection to the NUCAPT facility;

 

Community Outreach: As part of IMaD, a Science Communication intern was hired for 3 years to help present IMaD projects to targeted stakeholders, such as the general public, potential industrial partners, and state and federal legislators.  In Year 1, a graduate student in the Medill School of Journalism at NU, created a short-video series on materials, manufacturing, and data science. In Year 2, another graduate student in the Medill School of Journalism at NU, continued to work on this video series and to visit partner institutions to develop video content to provide the community more context on each partner project.  In Year 3 and 4, two interns, Medill School of Journalism at NU created a podcast series aimed at the general public, high school students, and college undergraduates, entitled ?Materials Data Matters? which was released on Apple podcasts.
